qas.question: Which areas in Antartica are considered polar deserts?

answers.text: Banks Island, and the McMurdo Dry Valleys

qas.question: Why can't glaciers form in polar deserts?
Does cold or warm air facilitate the transport of water vapor?
What is inevitable at hight latitudes?
What kind of deserts do glaciers form in?
What formed in central and north Alaska during the last ice age due to the extreme cold?

context: Even at high latitudes, <b3_0>glacier formation<b3_0/> is not inevitable. Areas of the Arctic, such as <a0_0>Banks Island, and the McMurdo Dry Valleys<a0_0/> in Antarctica are considered <b4_0>polar deserts<b4_0/> where glaciers cannot form because <a1_0>they receive little snowfall<a1_0/> despite the bitter cold. Cold air, unlike <a2_0>warm air<a2_0/>, is unable to transport much <b5_0>water vapor<b5_0/>. Even during glacial periods of the Quaternary, Manchuria, lowland Siberia, and central and northern Alaska, though extraordinarily cold, had such light snowfall that <b6_0>glaciers<b6_0/> could not form.
